title: Why should I study economics? - Quora

response.answer_text: Economics is a social science that deals with the production, use and transfer of wealth. It concerns issues that impact on financial situations and examines the distribution of wealth among-st organizations and individuals. It incorporates a number of subject areas such as politics, law, sociology and geography. There are a variety of different areas of economics you could explore or specialist in. Some of these areas are: Development economics - focuses on the development process in low-income countriesBusiness economics - the application of economic theory and methodology to business and businessesEnvironmental economics - concerns the economic impact of environmental policiesMacroeconomics - covers large-scale economics factors.A degree in economics covers current real-world issues. While the course has a focus on mathematics and its application to economics, it also includes a theoretical aspect to build an understanding of economic models within different societies. You will learn how organization and individuals make international decisions and how to forecast potential changes in the world of economics. Reasons for studying economics Economics is a broad field that offers a variety of benefits. A few of the reasons to study economics at university include: Strong job prospects A degree in economics is highly respected by employers. You will gain a strong knowledge of how the world works and a variety of highly transferable skills that are sought after by a range of industries and employers. Examples of the jobs that you could pursue include: StockbrokerEconomistData analystChartered accountantStatisticianMarket research analystEconomic consultantYou will also be qualified to work in jobs not directly related to your degree. Some of these jobs include: Business development managerData scientistManagement consultantPolicy officerCredit analystHighly desirable transferable skills Studying a degree in economics will give you a range of subject-specific skills that allow you to apply your knowledge of economics to real-world situations. The transferable skills you learn from economics are sought after by a variety of employers, whether you are looking to pursue a related economic career or explore other fields. You will have a unique way of thinking that you can apply to everyday problems. You will develop a range of skills such as: Critical thinkingCommunicationNumeracyResearch skillsCommercial and cultural awarenessData analysisTime managementTeamworkProblem-solvingComputingUnderstanding of how the world functions Economics is an important part of the world around us. It affects everything from how much we pay for goods and services to how much employees get paid. Studying economics at university gives you a new view of the world and how it functions when it comes to business and economics. Gain a unique pool of knowledge Studying an economics degree can be very rewarding and can be a great option if you want to have a wide range of opportunities after graduating. It opens up a number of paths thanks to the skills and variety of subjects it uses. You will explore questions that are key to the world’s economy, from what causes an economic crisis to how wealth is distributed around the globe. Economics is a degree that covers aspects of politics, sociology, psychology, history, mathematics, business, finance and international relations giving you strong general knowledge. Have you ever turned on the news, and watched a couple of people yammer for an hour about the interest rate and how it reflects on the economy, while you sat there scratching your head and wondering how the heck this has anything to do with you? Have you ever debated whether or not to finally buy a new car, now that the only thing that's reliable about your old car is that it'll break every Thursday? Has the thought "well, I'd love to have a new car, but I've put so much money into the repair costs just now so it just doesn't pay to replace the old one" ever entered your mind?  Have you ever seen a protest, in which people are yelling at the government to raise the minimum wage, and asked yourself "well, why not? Why shouldn't everyone who works earn more money?".  Have you ever wondered why housing prices (not everywhere, of course, but I'll use my country - Israel - as an example) seem to only be going up and up and up?  These situations - along with hundreds of others that you're experiencing on a daily basis - are the reason why we should all be taking an interest in economics. Because once you’ve studied economics, you'd know that $100 now is usually worth more than $100 in the future (unless inflation - a sustained increase in the general level of prices for goods and services, which essentially means that your money is worth less - is high) because the $100 that you have right now could be invested in the bank, in the stock market, in real estate, or in many other projects, and turn into, say, $105 in a year from now (as in, a 5% increase). Therefore, it's good to know what the banks’ interest rate is, as your money can be invested there, or alternatively - that how much you might be paying if you were to take out a loan. And once you’ve studied economics, you’d know that the money that you've already put into your lousy old car is a sunk cost - meaning, you've already paid the money and you're not getting it back - and therefore shouldn't be taken account into your decision of whether or not to replace it. What should be taken into account is how much the new car would cost: how much cash would be paid upfront and how much interest would you be adding when you pay back the loan; how much repairs would cost for the new and old car in the future, gas prices, depreciation (how much of its value a product loses), etc. Since you'd already know how to take into account how much a future cost translates to in present value terms, you'd be able to determine if buying a new car is worthwhile. And once you've studied economics, you'd know that the minimum wage is far more complicated than just giving some workers more money. The money would be coming from the employer's pockets, and if the employee is creating a lower profit for the employer than the new wages he's given, that employer may very well fire that employee. Some employers (who aren't necessarily part of corporations, they could easily be privately owned businesses or partnerships!) would even be forced to close shop because their business model no longer works, and they'd be unemployed as well. Perhaps, then, the protesters who are championing raising the minimum wage are in fact mistaken, and you, now knowledgeable in the ways of economics, can see the other side of things as well. You’d also be a far more well-informed citizen on matters such as housing prices. You’d know that what sets the prices for housing is the supply of houses and the demand for them, and that if the supply is low yet the demand is high, that means that there are many people desperately looking for a house in an area in which there are few available, and are consequently willing to pay more for the privilege of living there. You’d understand that while some governments try and manipulate the markets by using price ceilings and other techniques which sound fancy on the news, they’re just doing it for the sake of being reelected and they have no idea how the economy actually works. Do yourself a favor - pick up an economics textbook, which will describe in great detail what the words I’ve highlighted in bold mean. You’ll learn far more about the world you live in, and let me tell you - you will not regret it.
